<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 195, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 195, 907, 208]]<|/det|>
9709/11

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 217, 358, 231]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1 (P1)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 217, 907, 231]]<|/det|>
May/June 2011

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 240, 907, 253]]<|/det|>
1 hour 45 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 259, 460, 273]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 273, 390, 287]]<|/det|>
Graph Paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 287, 463, 301]]<|/det|>
List of Formulae (MF9)

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 322, 390, 336]]<|/det|>
# READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 352, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 368, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 327, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 497, 415]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 601, 431]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 285, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 907, 493]]<|/det|>
Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 494, 589, 508]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 509, 606, 524]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 540, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 556, 756, 571]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 572, 440, 587]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 907, 618]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 865, 660, 880]]<|/det|>
This document consists of 4 printed pages.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 96, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 559, 107]]<|/det|>
Find the coefficient of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(x + \frac{2}{x^2}\right)^7\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 81, 918, 100]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 138, 97, 156]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 920, 172]]<|/det|>
The volume of a spherical balloon is increasing at a constant rate of \(50 \text{cm}^3\) per second. Find the rate of increase of the radius when the radius is \(10 \text{cm}\). [Volume of a sphere \(= \frac{4}{3} \pi r^3\).]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 156, 918, 173]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 203, 96, 222]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 203, 396, 222]]<|/det|>
(i) Sketch the curve \(y = (x - 2)^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 203, 920, 222]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 234, 153, 252]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 234, 920, 268]]<|/det|>
The region enclosed by the curve, the \(x\)-axis and the \(y\)-axis is rotated through \(360^{\circ}\) about the \(x\)-axis. Find the volume obtained, giving your answer in terms of \(\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 250, 920, 268]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 295, 92, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 303, 730, 565]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 584, 920, 635]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a prism \(ABCDPQRS\) with a horizontal square base \(APSD\) with sides of length \(6\mathrm{cm}\). The cross-section \(ABCD\) is a trapezium and is such that the vertical edges \(AB\) and \(DC\) are of lengths \(5\mathrm{cm}\) and \(2\mathrm{cm}\) respectively. Unit vectors \(\mathbf{i}\), \(\mathbf{j}\) and \(\mathbf{k}\) are parallel to \(AD\), \(AP\) and \(AB\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 650, 156, 668]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 648, 650, 668]]<|/det|>
Express each of the vectors \(\overrightarrow{CP}\) and \(\overrightarrow{CQ}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{i}\), \(\mathbf{j}\) and \(\mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 650, 920, 668]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 680, 153, 698]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 680, 520, 698]]<|/det|>
Use a scalar product to calculate angle \(PCQ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 680, 920, 698]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 726, 96, 745]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 726, 695, 745]]<|/det|>
(i) Show that the equation \(2\tan^2\theta \sin^2\theta = 1\) can be written in the form

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 752, 594, 772]]<|/det|>
\[2\sin^{4}\theta +\sin^{2}\theta -1 = 0.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 753, 920, 772]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 792, 153, 810]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 792, 648, 810]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(2\tan^2\theta \sin^2\theta = 1\) for \(0^\circ \leqslant \theta \leqslant 360^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 792, 920, 810]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 682, 92]]<|/det|>
The variables \(x, y\) and \(z\) can take only positive values and are such that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 100, 616, 119]]<|/det|>
\[z = 3x + 2y\quad \mathrm{and}\quad xy = 600.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 140, 153, 159]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 138, 364, 165]]<|/det|>
Show that \(z = 3x + \frac{1200}{x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 144, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 178, 153, 197]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 178, 594, 197]]<|/det|>
Find the stationary value of \(z\) and determine its nature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 233, 96, 252]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 707, 256]]<|/det|>
A curve is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = \frac{3}{(1 + 2x)^2}\) and the point \((1, \frac{1}{2})\) lies on the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 271, 154, 289]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 271, 405, 289]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 272, 920, 290]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 303, 153, 320]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 301, 757, 320]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(x\) for which the gradient of the curve is less than \(\frac{1}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 303, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 350, 96, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 348, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
A television quiz show takes place every day. On day 1 the prize money is \(\)1000.\(If this is not won the prize money is increased for day 2. The prize money is increased in a similar way every day until it is won. The television company considered the following two different models for increasing the prize money.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 416, 630, 435]]<|/det|>
Model 1: Increase the prize money by \(\)1000\(each day.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 438, 616, 457]]<|/det|>
Model 2: Increase the prize money by \(10\%\) each day.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 470, 920, 518]]<|/det|>
On each day that the prize money is not won the television company makes a donation to charity. The amount donated is \(5\%\) of the value of the prize on that day. After 40 days the prize money has still not been won. Calculate the total amount donated to charity

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 527, 151, 545]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 527, 311, 545]]<|/det|>
if Model 1 is used,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 528, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 552, 153, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 552, 311, 570]]<|/det|>
if Model 2 is used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 552, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 597, 96, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 606, 804, 742]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 761, 920, 795]]<|/det|>
In the diagram, \(OAB\) is an isosceles triangle with \(OA = OB\) and angle \(AOB = 2\theta\) radians. Arc \(PST\) has centre \(O\) and radius \(r\), and the line \(ASB\) is a tangent to the arc \(PST\) at \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 808, 153, 826]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 808, 638, 826]]<|/det|>
Find the total area of the shaded regions in terms of \(r\) and \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 808, 920, 826]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 840, 153, 857]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 839, 920, 873]]<|/det|>
In the case where \(\theta = \frac{1}{3}\pi\) and \(r = 6\), find the total perimeter of the shaded regions, leaving your answer in terms of \(\sqrt{3}\) and \(\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 857, 920, 875]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 890, 717, 908]]<|/det|>
[Questions 10 and 11 are printed on the next page.]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 75, 153, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Express \(2x^{2} - 4x + 1\) in the form \(a(x + b)^{2} + c\) and hence state the coordinates of the minimum point, \(A\), on the curve \(y = 2x^{2} - 4x + 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
The line \(x - y + 4 = 0\) intersects the curve \(y = 2x^{2} - 4x + 1\) at points \(P\) and \(Q\). It is given that the coordinates of \(P\) are (3, 7).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 168, 151, 185]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 168, 371, 185]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 168, 920, 186]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 198, 153, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 198, 658, 216]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the line joining \(Q\) to the mid-point of \(AP\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 199, 920, 217]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 244, 104, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 244, 453, 262]]<|/det|>
Functions f and g are defined for \(x \in \mathbb{R}\) by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 271, 561, 288]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}:x\mapsto 2x + 1,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 292, 559, 310]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{g}:x\mapsto x^{2} - 2.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 330, 153, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 330, 559, 348]]<|/det|>
Find and simplify expressions for \(\operatorname {fg}(x)\) and \(\operatorname {gf}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 330, 920, 348]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 361, 153, 378]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 361, 559, 378]]<|/det|>
Hence find the value of \(a\) for which \(\operatorname {fg}(a) = \operatorname {gf}(a)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 361, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 392, 151, 410]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 392, 531, 410]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(b\) \((b \neq a)\) for which \(\operatorname {g}(b) = b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 393, 920, 411]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 424, 151, 442]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 424, 514, 442]]<|/det|>
Find and simplify an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}\mathrm{g}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 424, 920, 443]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 454, 346, 472]]<|/det|>
The function h is defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 475, 608, 494]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{h}:x\mapsto x^{2} - 2,\quad \mathrm{for} x\leqslant 0.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 510, 153, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 400, 528]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\mathrm{h}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 510, 920, 528]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]
